column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction

#Text=Phosphorus ( P ) and potassium ( K ) are the most significant macronutrients in the soil ecosystem after nitrogen ( N ) , which involves various processes , i.e. , energy formation , nucleic acid synthesis , photosynthesis , glycolysis , respiration , enzymes activation and redox reactions .
#Text=Nutrient management is important for sustainable crop production .
#Text=P- and K-efficient cultivars are important options in an agro-ecosystem .
#Text=Uptake efficiencies of nutrients such as P and K are related to the abilities of plants to produce high yields in low-nutrient conditions .
#Text=Deficiency in P is mainly attributed to its immobilization in soil .
#Text=Low K content is highly dependent on soil composition , especially on its fixation to clay particles , leading to deficiency in plant uptake .
#Text=Immobilized P can be re-mobilized , and non-exchangeable K can also become available in soil solution under biochemical processes .
#Text=However , they could be strongly dependent on soil chemistry

#Text=Exploitation of legumes is an essential approach for sustainable agriculture as it can increase nutrient cycling and promote soil fertility This approach can also potentially improve P and K availability in the soil , which is beneficial for plant uptake and soil microorganisms .

#Text=Root growth and root morphological mechanisms of leguminous plants are the principal factors that usually require greater P and K levels in the soil , which is also related to plant P and K uptake .

#Text=Several green manure crops such as white lupin ( Lupines albas L. ) , chickpea ( Cicer arietinum L. ) , field pea ( Pisum sativum L ) , and faba bean ( Vicia faba ) , are able to mobilize soil P through a variety of root mechanisms .
#Text=Recent studies have shown that legumes can regulate soil enzymatic activities more than mineral fertilizers .
#Text=According to other researchers , legumes such as chickpeas and cowpeas increase phosphatase enzyme activities more than non-legumes .
#Text=Soil enzymes play important roles in catalyzing reactions and are associated , directly or indirectly , with nutrient availability and organic matter decomposition .
#Text=The specific activity of an enzyme is not considered useful in the complete nutrient cycle of soil because it has a particular substrate .

#Text=Some hydrolytic enzymes ( e.g. , β-glucosidase , N-acetyl-glucosaminidase , Leucine-aminopeptidase , and phosphatase ) , which are related to C , N , and P cycles , are more responsible for the soil properties ( pH and soil organic matter ) than other variables .
#Text=Such enzymes could be valuable as early indicators of biological soil modification .

#Text=Leguminous plants , especially broad bean ( V. faba ) , Chinese milk vetch ( Astragalus sinicus L. ) , clover ( Trifolium repens L. ) , and hairy vetch ( V. villosa L. ) , have been used in crop rotation systems worldwide .

#Text=Although , P and K uptake efficiencies have been reported to be different in various legumes crops , and the relative knowledge and profound information about leguminous green manures in South China are still unclear .
#Text=Moreover , less information exists in the literature about the changes in enzymatic activities in response to cultivation of different legume species in the field .
#Text=Green manuring has become a popular practice in South China to improve soil fertility and rice yields at present .
#Text=The most popular winter green manure is milk vetch , which has traditionally been used for several thousands of years , and most attention has focused on N utilization .

#Text=The main objectives of this study were to ( 1 ) evaluate P and K uptake capabilities in various winter leguminous green manure species in South China and ( 2 ) investigate their ability to affect soil enzyme activity by interacting with soil properties .
